items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: This is an update to the Flood Alert issued yesterday 21/08/24 at 4:44 PM. The tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning 23/08/24  is expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions and spring tides. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The high water level is expected to reach 1.22mAOD at 12:24 AM with southerly force 6 winds. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Thursday 22 August.  

High water at Falmouth is at 8.12pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas.  

Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas along the tidal river Helford and exposed coastal locations including Portmellon seafront, Mevagissey Harbour area, and Portholland.   

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.    

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.65m AOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.11m - 0.13m above the tide table level.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.81 mAOD at 06:00 on 23/08/24 and 4.64 mAOD at 18:15 on 23/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 15 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 2 days, peaking this evening Thursday 22/08/24. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks. 
Sharpness 9.9 to 10.3m at 23:15 on 22/08/2024, and 9.3 to 9.9m at 11:30 on 23/08/2024. 
This morning’s tide, 22/08/24, peaked at Sharpness at 10.1m.
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 120mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Thursday evening is 5.26 mAOD, this is 0.12 metres above astronomical tide level. 
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is 5.04 mAOD, this is 0.16 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. The first peak high water level at West Bay Harbour is at 9:00 PM this evening 21/08/24 with a level of 2.50 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Thursday mornings tide 22/08/24 will not quite reach our threshold for a flood alert,  but tomorrow evenings tide at 9:43PM will exceed threshold with a predicted level of 2.52 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Tide levels will start dropping from Friday mornings tide onwards. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. People in the areas should consider taking action now. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss.

items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge following Storm Lilian moving across the North East. Strong winds may cause large waves along the Wear Estuary tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:15AM and 07:15AM, 23/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The areas most likely to be affected are Sunderland Marine Walk Outer, Sunderland North Estuary Footpath, Sunderland East Nobles Quay and Fatfield to Queen Alexander Bridge.
 
This alert is in force for this evenings tide (Thursday 22/08/2024), but the biggest flood risk impacts will be on the Friday morning tide (23/08/2024). Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings. 
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been issued due a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge following Storm Lilian moving across the North East.
The high tide time is forecast at 06:15 on 23/08/2024, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.
Flooding is expected at properties including the Amusement Arcades and Grannie Annies.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no further flood warnings are expected for following tides on Friday and Saturday.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast between 7:15am to 11:15am, tomorrow morning, 23/08/24.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4:62 mAODN at 9.15am, on Friday 23 August 2024, which is 0.07m below tide tables, wind Force 8, South-Westernly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Saturday 24 August 2024 at 10:15 am is currently below the Flood Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation.  We will update this message by 11.30 am tomorrow, Friday 23 August 2024.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Friday's early morning tide at 02:30 on 23/08/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 6.22 metres Chart Datum (3.17 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Friday afternoon's tide at 14:45 on 23/08/2024 is forecast to be 5 cm lower (3.12 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are predicted to continue until Saturday 24/08/2024 for each high tide. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 23/08/2024.

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tide on Friday 23 August.  

High water at Padstow is at 8.33am, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including low-lying areas of Port Quinn, Port Isaac, Port Gaverne, Boscastle Harbour, Crooklets and The Strand and The Crescent in Bude.  

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.  

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 5pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.    

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Padstow is 4.02m AOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.13m - 0.16m above the tide table level.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse, Don and the Dutch River catchment

floodArea.county: Doncaster, East Riding of Yorkshire, North Lincolnshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, River Don, Dutch River

items.message:
High tides, strong winds from Storm Lilian and large waves tomorrow morning (Friday 23/08/24) may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at the south bank of the River Ouse from Airmyn to Whitgift and the River Don and Dutch River from Thorne to Goole at 10:00 AM on Friday 23/08/24. Flooding is possible 1-2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include The south bank of the River Ouse from Airmyn to Whitgift and the River Don and Dutch River from Thorne to Goole. Flooding is possible at West Holme washland, Birkin Holme washland, Roall Ings,Hensall Ings, West Marsh washland, Gowdall Ings and Snaith Ings.
Tidal conditions are expected to start improving from tomorrow afternoon (Friday 23/08/24) and over the weekend and no flooding is currently expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and undertaking patrols where necessary. Associated British Ports – Goole are closing Victoria and Ocean lock gates. 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 7:30 AM on Friday 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tides of Thursday 22 August and Friday 23 August.  

High water at Falmouth is at 8.12pm on Thursday and 8:56pm on Friday.  

Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 5 south westerly winds are forecast to cause flooding of waterside locations and roads.   

Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Devoran, Calenick, Truro and the A390 at Tresillian. 

The tidal gates at Flushing will be closed.  

Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Friday 23 August, or earlier if the situation changes.  

Detailed tidal information for those who use it:  

Thursday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.65m AOD.  

Friday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.48m AOD.  

Expect tide levels along to coast to be between 0.11m - 0.13m above tide table level.
